case_name: the appellant v. State of Maharashtra

facts.text: This is Civil Appeal No. 442 of 1965 from the judgment and decree dated August 10, 1961 of the Bombay High Court in Appeal No. 23 of 1960.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 442 of 1965. Appeal from the judgment and decree dated August 10, 1961 of the Bombay High Court in Appeal No. 23 of 1960.

facts.text: The appellant was a member of the Bombay Medical Service, Class II and employee of the State of Maharashtra.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant was a member of the Bombay Medical Service, Class 11 and as such was an employee of the State of Maharashtra.

facts.text: In 1943, the appellant was posted at the Civil Hospital, Ahmedabad.

anchor.surface_text: In 1943, the appellant was posted at the Civil Hospital, Ahmedabad and on February 18, 1950 he was in- charge of the Medico-Legal Section of that hospital.

facts.text: On February 18, 1950, the appellant was in-charge of the Medico-Legal Section of the Civil Hospital, Ahmedabad.

anchor.surface_text: and on February 18, 1950 he was in- charge of the Medico-Legal Section of that hospital. On January 19, 1950, one Nabimahomed companyplained to Mr. Rathod, Sub-Inspector of Police Anti-Corruption Branch,

facts.text: On January 19, 1950, Nabimahomed complained to Mr. Rathod, Sub-Inspector of Police Anti-Corruption Branch, Ahmedabad, implicating the appellant.

anchor.surface_text: On January 19, 1950, one Nabimahomed companyplained to Mr. Rathod, Sub-Inspector of Police Anti-Corruption Branch, Ahmedabad, implicated by the Anti-Corruption Branch of the Police

facts.text: Surgeon-General forwarded the report of Sub-Inspector Rathod and the appellant's representation to the State Government by letter dated February 1, 1950, recommending suspension.

anchor.surface_text: The Surgeon-General forwarded the report of Sub-Inspector, Mr. Rathod as well as the representation of the appellant to the State Government by his letter dated February 1, 1950. He requested the Government that in the circumstances

facts.text: Recommendation for suspension approved by Minister for Health and Chief Minister.

anchor.surface_text: mentioned in the Sub- Inspectors report orders may be issued for placing the appellant under suspension. His recommendation was approved by the Minister for Health and by the Chief Minister.

facts.text: By letter dated February 13, 1950, Deputy Secretary informed Surgeon-General that appellant should be suspended with immediate effect pending further orders.

anchor.surface_text: By a letter dated February 13, 1950, the Deputy Secretary to the Government informed the Surgeon-General that the appellant should be suspended with immediate effect pending further orders

facts.text: Surgeon-General issued order dated February 16, 1950 to Civil Surgeon, Ahmedabad to place appellant under suspension from date of receipt.

anchor.surface_text: The Surgeon-General thereafter issued an order to the Civil Surgeon, Ahmedabad dated February 16, 1950 that the appellant should be placed under suspension pending further orders from the date of the receipt of the memorandum.

facts.text: Civil Surgeon issued office order suspending appellant with effect from afternoon of February 18, 1950.

anchor.surface_text: In pursuance of the directions received by him from the Surgeon-General, the Civil Surgeon, Ahmedabad, issued the following office order and sent it to the appellant Under orders from the Surgeon-General, with the Government of Bombay, companyveyed in his Memorandum No. S. 97/189/A dated 16th February, 1950, you are informed that you are suspended pending further orders with effect from the afternoon of 18th instant.

facts.text: On August 21, 1950, Government directed subsistence allowance at specified rates from February 19, 1950 onwards, plus dearness and house rent allowances.

anchor.surface_text: On August 21, 1950 the Government directed that the appellant should be allowed subsistence allowance at Rs. 153-5-0 per mensem from the date of his suspension February 19, 1950 to March 31, 1950, at Rs. 158-13-0 per mensem from April 1, 1950 to February 18, 1951 and at Rs. 119-2-0 per mensem from February 19, 1951 onwards.

facts.text: On May 6, 1950, sanction given for prosecution of appellant under section 161, Indian Penal Code.

anchor.surface_text: On May 6, 1950 sanction was given for the prosecution of the appellant under s. 161, Indian Penal Code.

facts.text: On February 26, 1951, appellant convicted by First Class City Magistrate at Ahmedabad and sentenced to one day's imprisonment and fine of Rs. 1000.

anchor.surface_text: On February 26, 1951 the appellant was companyvicted by the First Class City Magistrate at Ahmedabad and sentenced to one days imprisonment and a fine of Rs. 1000/- .

facts.text: Appellant's appeal to Sessions Court dismissed.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant filed an appeal to the Sessions Court, but his appeal was dismissed.

facts.text: Bombay High Court allowed revision application, set aside conviction and sentence.

anchor.surface_text: Thereafter, the appellant took the matter in revision to the Bombay High Court. The revision application was allowed and the companyviction and sentence passed against the appellant were set aside.

facts.text: On March 14, 1952, appellant made representation to Government for reinstatement.

anchor.surface_text: On March 14, 1952, the appellant made a representation to the Government praying that he should be reinstated in service.

facts.text: Government applied to High Court for leave to appeal to Supreme Court, rejected; then special leave to Supreme Court rejected on October 13, 1952.

anchor.surface_text: The Government, however, applied to the High Court for- leave to appeal to this Court against the decision if the High Court and on the said application being rejected, the Government applied to this Court for special leave to appeal. This Court rejected the application on October 13, 1952.

facts.text: On February 20, 1953, Government directed departmental enquiry against appellant, Civil Surgeon appointed Inquiry Officer to complete within three months.

anchor.surface_text: On February 20, 1953 the Government directed that a departmental enquiry should be held against the appellant. The Civil Surgeon, Ahmedabad was appointed Inquiry Officer and he was asked to companyplete the inquiry within three months and submit his report to the Government through the Surgeon-General.

facts.text: Departmental inquiry delayed, order of dismissal made against appellant on February 11, 1960.

anchor.surface_text: For reasons which are number apparent the departmental inquiry was delayed and ultimately an order of dismissal was made against the appellant on February 11, 1960.

facts.text: On April 11, 1953, appellant filed suit against respondent for declaration that suspension order illegal, continued in service, remuneration and allowances from suspension date till reinstatement.

anchor.surface_text: On April 11, 1953 the appellant brought the present suit against the respondent praying for a declaration that the order of suspension was illegal and inoperative in law and the appellant companytinued in service as though numberorder for suspension had been passed. The appellant claimed remuneration and allowances with usual increments from the date of his suspension till the date of his reinstatement.

facts.text: Respondent controverted allegations, asserted suspension not illegal.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent companytroverted the allegations made in the plaint and asserted that the suspension of the appellant was number illegal.

facts.text: M. Shah J. held appellant entitled to salary and allowances up to February 11, 1960, granted declaration suspension illegal, decree for Rs. 51,135.28 with interest.

anchor.surface_text: Shah, J. of the Bombay High Court before whom the suit was tried held that the appellant was entitled to salary and allowances upto the date when he was dismissed i.e., February 11, 1960. He granted to the appellant a declaration that the order of suspension was illegal and inoperative in law and the appellant companytinued to be on duty till February 11, 1960 as though numberorder of suspension had been made. He also granted a decree directing the respondent to pay to the appellant Rs. 51,135.28 with interest on Rs. 43,223/- at the rate of 4 per cent p.a.

facts.text: Bombay High Court Appellate Bench (Chief Justice and Mody J.) held suspension valid under Rule 151, suit barred by Article 14 Limitation Act, allowed appeal, dismissed suit.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent appealed against the judgment of the trial Judge. The appeal was heard by a Bench companysisting of the Chief Justice and Mody, J. The Appellate Bench held that the respondent had inherent power to suspend the appellant and to withhold full remuneration for the period of suspension under Rule 151 of the Bombay Civil Services Rules. ... For these reasons the Appellate Bench allowed the appeal, set aside the decree passed by the trial Judge and dismissed the suit

facts.text: Appeal to Supreme Court brought by certificate from Bombay High Court judgment.

anchor.surface_text: This appeal is brought, by certificate, from judgment of the Bombay High Court dated August 10, 1961 by which the appeal of the respondent against the judgment of M. Shah, J. of that High Court was allowed and the suit of the appellant was dismissed.

facts.text: Supreme Court held that Government had power to suspend appellant by order dated February 13, 1950 under Rule 151 Bombay Civil Services Rules.

anchor.surface_text: We are accordingly of the opinion that Rule 151 empowers the State Government to withhold pay for the period of interim suspension but the Government servant is entitled under that rule to a subsistence allowance at such rate as the suspending authority may direct but number exceeding one-fourth of his pay.

anchor.surface_text: We see no warrant for accepting this argument. Suspension is used in Rule 151 in a general sense and Rule 151 applies to all kinds of suspension, whether it is imposed by way of penalty or as an interim measure pending departmental inquiry or a criminal proceeding.

holdings.text: The State Government had the power to suspend the appellant by its order dated February 13, 1950 pending enquiry into his alleged misconduct as the appointing authority

anchor.surface_text: The first question to be considered in this appeal is whether Government had the power to suspend the appellant by its order dated February 13, 1950 pending enquiry into his alleged misconduct. It was contended on behalf of the appellant that the power to suspend is not an implied term in an ordinary contract between master and servant and that such a power can only be the creature either of a statute governing the contract, or of an express term in the contract itself.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Rejected implied contract argument; applied general law from SC precedents (Hotel Imperial, Cajee, Kapur); appointing authority has inherent power to suspend pending enquiry, subject to rules on pay

holdings.text: Rule 151 of the Bombay Civil Services Rules applies to all kinds of suspension including interim suspension pending departmental inquiry or criminal proceeding and empowers withholding of full pay with subsistence allowance not exceeding one-fourth of pay

anchor.surface_text: We are accordingly of the opinion that Rule 151 empowers the State Government to withhold pay for the period of interim suspension but the Government servant is entitled under that rule to a subsistence allowance at such rate as the suspending authority may direct but number exceeding one-fourth of his pay.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Textual interpretation of 'suspension' in general sense; harmonious construction with Rules 153, 156; analogy to Fundamental Rule 53 upheld in Kapur v. Union of India

holdings.text: The order of suspension dated February 13, 1950 suspending the appellant pending further orders did not come to an end automatically on his acquittal by the High Court on February 15, 1952
holdings.reasoning_summary: Textual reading of order as 'pending further orders' requires explicit termination; distinguished Orissa High Court case on different rule and wording

holdings.text: The order of suspension dated February 13, 1950 was legally valid

anchor.surface_text: It follows therefore that the order of the State Government dated February 13, 1950 suspending the appellant pending enquiry into his conduct was legally valid and the argument of the appellant on this aspect of the case must be rejected.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Combines general appointing power with application of Rule 151 to interim suspension permitting withholding of pay
